head.citation-title: Flavonoids and carotenoids in silkworm cocoons
head.abstracts: Silk consists of natural fibers produced by a variety of insects including silkworms belonging to Lepidopteran, Bombycidae and Saturniidae families. Commonly-known silk is obtained from cocoons encapsulating larvae of the mulberry silkworm, Bombyx mori, reared in sericulture facilities. Silk emitted by the silkworm consists of two main proteins, sericin and fibroin. Fibroin being the structural center of the silk, whereas sericin being rubbery coating material surrounding the fibroin core. Different strains of silkworm yield fibroin and sericin with varying molecular structures, which may account for different biological activities that may become the basis of variety of applications. In addition to sericin and fibroin, silk from B. Mori, particularly the colored strains, contains pigments that are mostly associated with carotenoids and flavonoids. The possible role for carotenoids in disease prevention of common chronic human disease such as cancer, age-related macular degeneration and cardiovascular diseases has stimulated wide interest in this compound as well as its absorption and metabolism. Composition of the cocoon coloring components varies depending on silk strains. Although it is generally accepted that genetic variation results in different patterns of fibroin and sericin, as well as pigment, composition of the silk cocoons, thorough compilation remains to be made in regards to their molecular structures as well as physical and biological activities. © 2012 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

coredata.dc:description: Silk consists of natural fibers produced by a variety of insects including silkworms belonging to Lepidopteran, Bombycidae and Saturniidae families. Commonly-known silk is obtained from cocoons encapsulating larvae of the mulberry silkworm, Bombyx mori, reared in sericulture facilities. Fibroin being the structural center of the silk, whereas sericin being rubbery coating material surrounding the fibroin core. Different strains of silkworm yield fibroin and sericin with varying molecular structures, which may account for different biological activities that may become the basis of variety of applications. In addition to sericin and fibroin, silk from B. Mori, particularly the colored strains, contains pigments that are mostly associated with carotenoids and flavonoids. The possible role for carotenoids in disease prevention of common chronic human disease such as cancer, age-related macular degeneration and cardiovascular diseases has stimulated wide interest in this compound as well as its absorption and metabolism. Composition of the cocoon coloring components varies depending on silk strains. Although it is generally accepted that genetic variation results in different patterns of fibroin and sericin, as well as pigment, composition of the silk cocoons, thorough compilation remains to be made in regards to their molecular structures as well as physical and biological activities. © 2012 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc.
